questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the office because of a rash on his nose. A month ago, the patient noticed several small spots on his nose that have progressively enlarged but are not pruritic or painful. Past medical history is significant for primary syphilis and anal gonorrhea, both of which were adequately treated with antibiotics a few years ago. The patient has had 4 female sexual partners over the past year. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9 F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Physical examination findings are shown below. HIV testing is positive. CD4+ count is 150/mm3, and HIV viral load is 47,000 copies/mL. In addition to antiretroviral therapy, which of the following medications should be added to this patient’s medication regimen?  

.
Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient with HIV is presenting with Kaposi sarcoma. He has a CD4+ cell count of less than <200/mm3 but more than >50/mm3 and should, therefore, receive prophylaxis against Pneumocystis jirovecii and Toxoplasma gondii with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX).   

TMP-SMX is a combination of antimetabolite drugs that sequentially block the synthesis of bacterial folic acid synthesis (act synergistically) and is bactericidal against susceptible organisms (e.g., E. coli, Klebsiella, Salmonella, and Shigella). It is most commonly used to treat simple urinary tract infections. Other indications include pneumonia and sinus infections caused by Haemophilus influenzae and Moraxella catarrhalis, respectively, as well as the prevention of Pneumocystis jiroveci and Toxoplasma infections (in organ and stem cell transplant recipients and HIV/AIDS patients with CD4 counts less than 200/mm3).    

The sulfonamides (e.g., sulfadiazine, sulfasalazine, sulfacetamide, and sulfadoxine) are active against Gram-positive and Gram-negative organisms, Chlamydia, and Nocardia. Specific indications include: 
  •  Sulfadiazine with pyrimethamine for the treatment of acute toxoplasmosis 
  •  Sodium sulfacetamide for the treatment of bacterial conjunctivitis and as adjunctive therapy for trachoma 
  •  Sulfasalazine for the treatment of ulcerative colitis and enteritis 


Option Analysis

❌ Penicillin:
Incorrect: Penicillin is indicated for the prophylaxis of acute rheumatic fever in patients with streptococcal pharyngitis, pregnant women carrying group B streptococcus infection, and strep pharyngitis in children with prior rheumatic fever.  
❌ Rifampin :
Incorrect: Rifampin chemoprophylaxis is indicated in close contact with patients with meningococcal infection and should be given as early as possible following exposure. It does not prevent the development of opportunistic infections in patients with HIV.  
❌ Azithromycin :
Incorrect: Azithromycin is occasionally indicated in HIV patients with a CD4+ count <50/mm3 to prevent opportunistic infection with Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC). This was previously administered to all individuals with a CD4+ count <50/mm3, but recent guideline changes now recommend not giving it to all patients, and only for patients residing in areas with high rates of MAC infection.   
✅ Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mefloquine:
Incorrect: Mefloquine is effective for the prevention of malaria due to chloroquine-sensitive, and chloroquine-resistant P. falciparum, as well as the other malaria species that cause human malaria. It does not prevent the development of opportunistic infections in patients with HIV.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of extreme fatigue that has been ongoing for several weeks. Eight months ago, he was diagnosed with HIV infection and started on combined antiretroviral treatment. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 132/84 mmHg, pulse is 98/min, and respirations are 16/min. Laboratory evaluation is shown below. Administration of which of the following medications will most effectively improve this patient’s condition?  

Laboratory Value  
Result
Hemoglobin
9.1 g/dL  
Leukocyte Count
800/mm3   
Platelet Count
50,000/mm3
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fatigue, decreased hemoglobin level, and decreased platelet and leukocyte counts. Given the patient’s history of HIV infection, these findings concern nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI)-related bone marrow suppression, which is the major dose-related toxicity of zidovudine.

Filgrastim, a recombinant granulocyte-colony stimulating factor (G-CSF), is commonly used to treat drug-induced neutropenia. G-CSF stimulates common myeloid progenitors to become myeloblasts and then induces myeloblasts to become either neutrophils or basophils.

Epoetin alfa, which is recombinant erythropoietin, can be used for patients with drug-induced anemia.

Finally, a prophylactic platelet concentrate transfusion can be performed for patients with severe thrombocytopenia (platelet count less than 10,000/mm3).  

Option Analysis

❌ Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole:
Incorrect: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is often used in patients with advanced HIV to prevent Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia and Toxoplasma gondii infection. It has no role in the reversal of NRTI-related bone marrow suppression.  
❌ Azithromycin:
Incorrect: Azithromycin is an antibiotic used to treat and prevent Mycobacterium avium complex infection in patients with HIV. It has no role in the reversal of NRTI-related bone marrow suppression.  
✅ Filgrastim:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Clozapine:
Incorrect: Clozapine is a second-generation antipsychotic. This patient does not have an underlying condition that would warrant clozapine therapy.  
❌ Ganciclovir:
Incorrect: Ganciclovir is associated with bone marrow suppression, particularly leukopenia. It should be used with caution in patients with pre-existing cytopenias. This patient does not have clinical indications for ganciclovir therapy. If anything, the medication may further exacerbate the patient’s bone marrow suppression.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to an outpatient clinic for HIV follow-up. He has been feeling well and is asymptomatic. The patient has been compliant with his treatment regimen of bictegravir, tenofovir alafenamide, and emtricitabine; however, he continues to have an elevated HIV-1 viral load. The patient is prescribed maraviroc in addition to continuing the current highly active antiretroviral therapy regimen. What is the mechanism of action of this new medication?

choices.text: Inhibiting nucleotide binding to reverse transcriptase

questions.solution:
This patient is started on maraviroc, which works by binding to T-cell and monocyte CCR-5 receptors and preventing viral entry.  

Antiretroviral therapy (ART) is initiated at diagnosis of HIV infection. It typically consists of a 3-drug regimen, consisting of 2 nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) and an integrase inhibitor, to prevent resistance. There are newer classes of HIV medication that have been developed to address treatment-resistant strains of HIV.    

Entry inhibitors, also known as fusion inhibitors, are examples of such drugs. These medications are given to patients who show replication of HIV despite ongoing ART.    

In particular, maraviroc is an HIV medication that acts as an entry inhibitor by binding CCR-5 on the surface of T-cells and monocytes thereby blocking the interaction with gp120. It cannot be used against HIV strains that bind to CXCR4 and is thus used only as an add-on medication to HAART. Its main side effects include diarrhea, joint and muscle pain, jaundice, and transaminitis.   

Option Analysis

✅ Binding to CCR-5:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Binding to gp41:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of enfuvirtide. It is an injectable HIV medication that acts by binding to the viral gp41 protein and preventing viral entry into host cells. Unlike other HIV medications, which are active against HIV-1 and HIV-2, enfuvirtide is only active against HIV-1.   
❌ Inhibiting HIV integrase:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of integrase inhibitors. These medications block integration of the HIV genome into host cell chromosomes through reversible inhibition of HIV integrase. Common side effects include nausea, headache, as well as myopathy with an increased creatine kinase level.  
❌ Inhibiting HIV protease:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of protease inhibitors. By blocking viral protease, these medications are able to prevent HIV mRNA cleavage and the maturation of new viruses.   
❌ Inhibiting nucleotide binding to reverse transcriptase:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) and non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs). In contrast, maraviroc works by binding to CCR-5 on the surface of leukocytes and preventing it from interacting with viral gp120.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man comes to the office because of painful mouth ulcers, difficulty swallowing food, and fevers. He was recently diagnosed with HIV and started on antiretroviral medications and prophylactic trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole due to a low CD4+ cell count. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple aphthous ulcers in the oropharynx. A complete blood count is shown below. Coadministration of which of the following could have prevented this patient’s current condition?  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin  8 g/dL 
 Mean corpuscular volume  110 fL 
 Leukocyte count  3,000/mm3 
 Platelet count  100,000/mm3
questions.solution:
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) combinations act synergistically by blocking folic acid synthesis (which is the precursor of DNA synthesis). Inhibition of DNA synthesis predominantly affects the rapidly dividing cells of gastrointestinal tract mucosa (aphthous ulcer) and bone marrow (pancytopenia). Folinic acid (leucovorin) serves as a reduced form of folic acid and does not require dihydrofolate reductase (inhibited by trimethoprim). Therefore, pancytopenia can be avoided by the coadministration of folinic acid with trimethoprim. Hyperkalemia can also occur with high doses of trimethoprim. Moreover, due to their inhibition of folic acid synthesis, it can cause neural tube defects in the fetus of pregnant women.  

Sulfonamides, on the other hand, are associated with a variety of adverse effects which include: 
  •  Hypersensitivity reactions including skin rashes and fever 
  •  Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and mild hepatic dysfunction 
  •  Acute hemolysis may occur in persons with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency 
  •  It can precipitate in urine causing crystalluria and hematuria 
  •  Stevens-Johnson syndrome 
  •  Kernicterus in infants by displacing bilirubin from plasma proteins 
  •  It competes with warfarin and methotrexate for plasma protein binding transiently increases the plasma levels of these drugs 


Option Analysis

❌ Dexrazoxane:
Incorrect: Dexrazoxane is an iron-chelating agent used to prevent anthracycline-induced cardiotoxicity.  
❌ Allopurinol:
Incorrect: Allopurinol is a noncompetitive inhibitor of xanthine oxidase and is used in the treatment of gout and prevention of tumor lysis syndrome.  
❌ Mesna:
Incorrect: Hemorrhagic cystitis associated with the administration of cyclophosphamide can be prevented by aggressive hydration and coadministration of mesna, which binds and inactivates the toxic metabolites in urine.  
✅ Folinic acid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ondansetron:
Incorrect: Ondansetron is a serotonin receptor inhibitor used to treat nausea and vomiting secondary to chemotherapy.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents to his outpatient provider to evaluate fatigue and lymphadenopathy. He states the symptoms have been ongoing for two weeks. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient smokes one pack of cigarettes per day and has been sexually active with multiple female partners. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), blood pressure is 115/73 mmHg, and pulse is 78/min. Physical examination reveals enlargement of cervical, supraclavicular, and inguinal lymph nodes. The tonsils appear erythematous, but no exudate is present. Subsequent testing reveals the presence of p24 antigens and anti-HIV antibodies. The patient is started on several antiviral drugs, one of which may cause side effects, including fat redistribution, hyperlipidemia, and hyperglycemia. Which of the following viral proteins is most likely targeted by this drug?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with lymphadenopathy, fatigue, fever, and sore throat. Laboratory testing reveals the presence of HIV antigens and anti-HIV antibodies. The patient was likely started on a protease inhibitor as part of her treatment regimen.

Protease inhibitors (e.g., darunavir, indinavir, ritonavir) can be used to treat HIV infection. These medications bind and inhibit HIV-1 protease, thereby preventing the virus from processing the Gag-Pol polyproteins into its functional parts and thus impeding viral replication. Protease inhibitors are rarely used alone since HIV quickly develops resistance via point mutations of the pol gene, which is the gene that encodes HIV-1 protease. Typically, protease inhibitors are used as a part of the highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) combined with other drugs.

The most common side effects of protease inhibitors include gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., diarrhea, nausea, vomiting) and metabolic disorders (e.g., hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia). These metabolic disorders are often followed by lipodystrophy. Lipodystrophy is characterized by abnormal accumulation of fat tissue in the abdomen, breasts (in women), and over the cervical vertebrae and loss of fat in the extremities and face.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Nonstructural protein 5A:
Incorrect: Nonstructural protein 5A (NS5A) is found in the hepatitis C virus (HCV) and assists with viral RNA replication. This protein is targeted by medications such as ledipasvir, elbasvir, and daclatasvir. In contrast, these medications would be ineffective in treating infection by HIV, which lacks the NS5A protein.  
✅ Protease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Integrase:
Incorrect: Integrase inhibitors (e.g., raltegravir, dolutegravir) prevent viral DNA from integrating with the host’s DNA, impairing viral replication. These medications can cause elevated creatinine kinase, myopathy, and insomnia as side effects. However, integrase inhibitors would not typically cause fat redistribution, hyperglycemia, or hyperlipidemia.  
❌ Glycoprotein 41:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide is a fusion inhibitor that binds viral glycoprotein 41 (gp41) and prevents the virus from fusing with CD4 T-cells. Enfuvirtide may lead to injection site reactions but would not cause fat redistribution, hyperglycemia, or hyperlipidemia.  
❌ DNA polymerase:
Incorrect: A wide variety of antivirals, such as cidofovir, foscarnet, and acyclovir, work by inhibiting viral DNA polymerase and preventing viral replication. However, HIV does not have a DNA polymerase. As a result, these medications would be ineffective in treating HIV infection.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after an episode of hematemesis. The patient was at home watching television when she suddenly felt nauseous and subsequently vomited bright red blood. Past medical history is notable for atrial fibrillation diagnosed two years ago. She has been taking metoprolol and warfarin. In addition, she was diagnosed with HIV four months ago, for which she has been prescribed ritonavir. She does not use alcohol, tobacco, or recreational drugs. She had been sexually active with multiple partners before her HIV diagnosis. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 115/63 mmHg, and pulse is 107/min. Physical examination reveals dried blood in the oropharynx. Multiple bruises are present over the upper and lower extremities. Abdominal examination reveals no focal tenderness or hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory testing is compared with results from a prior visit four months earlier. The results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient’s current symptoms?  

Laboratory Value   
Results (today’s visit)   
Results (4 months ago)   
Hemoglobin
12.5 g/dL (1.88 mmol/L)  
10.8 g/dL (1.63 mmol/L)  
Platelet Count
250,000/mm3 (250*109/L)
220,000/mm3 (220*109/L)
Prothrombin Time (PT)
48 seconds  
28 seconds  
International Normalized Ratio (INR)  
4.5  
2.3

choices.text: Rupture of dilated veins within the esophagus
Invasion of the esophageal wall by opportunistic pathogens
Poor compliance with prescribed medication regimen

questions.solution:
This patient presents with hematemesis, skin bruising, and a markedly elevated PT/INR following initiation of ritonavir therapy. Ritonavir is a protease inhibitor that can be used to treat HIV infection. The drug binds and inhibits HIV-1 protease, thereby preventing the virus from processing Gag-Pol polyproteins into its functional parts and thus impeding viral replication.

One notable side effect of ritonavir is that it inhibits cytochrome P450. Cytochrome P450 is an enzyme found in the liver responsible for the metabolism of many medications, including warfarin, antiepileptics, statins, and oral contraceptives. As a result, ritonavir can lead to impaired clearance and increased serum concentration of the medications mentioned above. In the case of warfarin, elevated plasma levels can lead to elevated coagulation parameters and an increased risk for bleeding.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Rupture of dilated veins within the esophagus:
Incorrect: An esophageal variceal bleed can manifest with hematemesis. Esophageal varices typically develop in the setting of portal hypertension, which leads to the formation of collateral venous circulation and esophageal vein dilation. In contrast, this patient lacks findings suggestive of underlying portal hypertension or liver disease (e.g., jaundice, ascites, hepatosplenomegaly).  
✅ Impaired hepatic metabolism of medications:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Invasion of the esophageal wall by opportunistic pathogens:
Incorrect: Esophagitis caused by opportunistic pathogens (e.g., Candida albicans, cytomegalovirus) can cause dysphagia, odynophagia, and chest pain. In rare cases, these conditions can also cause hematemesis. However, esophagitis would not account for the elevation in PT/INR between the patient’s prior and current visit.  
❌ Poor compliance with prescribed medication regimen:
Incorrect: This patient’s INR was initially within the target range (2.0-3.0) but became markedly elevated after initiating ritonavir. Ritonavir can inhibit cytochrome P450 and impair warfarin metabolism. As a result, drug-drug interaction, as opposed to medication noncompliance, is the most likely cause of this patient’s elevated PT/INR and bleeding episode.  
❌ Reduced renal clearance of anticoagulants:
Incorrect: This patient’s INR was initially within the target range (2.0-3.0) but became markedly elevated after initiating ritonavir. Ritonavir can inhibit cytochrome P450 and impair warfarin metabolism. As a result, a decrease in hepatic metabolism, as opposed to a decrease in renal clearance, is most likely responsible for this patient’s elevated PT/INR and bleeding episode.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency room after being in close contact with an individual diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. The patient is a graduate student and lives in an apartment with several roommates. One of the roommates had recently fallen ill and was diagnosed with Neisseria meningitidis infection earlier today. The patient is currently asymptomatic but is worried he may have been exposed to the pathogen. His past medical history is notable for HIV infection, for which he currently takes lamivudine, lopinavir, and abacavir. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 119/72 mmHg, and pulse is 65/min. Physical examination is unremarkable, and no nuchal rigidity is present. The patient’s most recent CD4 cell count is 700/mm3. Which of the following medications should be administered for post-exposure prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
This patient requires post-exposure meningococcal prophylaxis. However, he is also taking several medications, including the protease inhibitor lopinavir, to treat HIV infection. While rifampin is often used for meningococcal prophylaxis, the medication can induce cytochrome P450 activity and cause the serum concentration of protease inhibitors (and other medications metabolized by cytochrome P450) to fall below therapeutic levels. As a result, patients with protease inhibitors should not be administered rifampin.

In the case of meningococcal prophylaxis, an alternative agent such as ceftriaxone or ciprofloxacin should be given since they are not known to induce cytochrome P450 activity. Furthermore, in the case of Mycobacterium tuberculosis treatment, rifabutin can be administered as an alternative to rifamycin.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Rifampin:
Incorrect: Rifampin can be used for post-exposure prophylaxis in close contact with individuals with meningococcal infection. However, rifampin induces cytochrome P450 and increases the metabolism of other medications. In this patient's case, rifampin may increase lopinavir (protease inhibitor) metabolism and cause serum concentrations to fall below therapeutic levels.  
❌ Azithromycin:
Incorrect: This individual has been in close contact with someone diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis and requires post-exposure prophylaxis. Azithromycin is a second-line prophylaxis agent and is generally administered to patients who cannot tolerate first-line agents (e.g., rifampin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin).  
✅ Ceftriaxone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rifabutin:
Incorrect: Rifabutin is part of the rifamycin antibiotic group. It can treat tuberculosis and prevent and treat Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection. However, rifabutin is ineffective in providing prophylaxis against Neisseria meningitidis and would not address the patient’s primary concern.  
❌ Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole:
Incorrect: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) can provide prophylaxis against opportunistic pathogens like Pneumocystis jiroveci and Toxoplasma gondii. However, TMP-SMX is largely ineffective in providing prophylaxis against Neisseria meningitidis.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents to an outpatient clinic for a routine visit. The patient was diagnosed with HIV infection 2 years ago. Current medications include emtricitabine, tenofovir, and dolutegravir. The patient is found to have persistently elevated HIV-1 levels despite being on highly active antiretroviral therapy. Enfuvirtide is added to the patient’s treatment regimen. Which of the following side effects is this patient at greatest risk of developing with this new medication?
questions.solution:
This patient is started on enfuvirtide, which is associated with injection site reactions such as erythema, induration, as well as nodule and cyst formation.  

Antiretroviral therapy (ART) is initiated at the diagnosis of HIV infection. It typically consists of a 3-drug regimen, consisting of 2 nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) and an integrase inhibitor, to prevent resistance. There are newer classes of HIV medication that have been developed to address treatment-resistant strains of HIV.    

Entry inhibitors, also known as fusion inhibitors, are examples of such drugs. These medications are given to patients who show replication of HIV despite ongoing ART.    

In particular, enfuvirtide acts as a viral entry inhibitor through the binding of the viral gp41 protein, which is involved in viral fusion with T-cells. It is given as a subcutaneous injection. Unlike other HIV medications which are active against HIV-1 and HIV-2, enfuvirtide is only active against HIV-1. Its main side effects are injection site reaction and an increased risk of bacterial infections, such as pneumonia.   

Option Analysis

❌ Increased creatine kinase (CK) levels:
Incorrect: The integrase inhibitors are associated with myopathy and increased CK levels. Examples include bictegravir, dolutegravir, elvitegravir, and raltegravir. They block the integration of the HIV genome into the host cell chromosome through reversible inhibition of HIV integrase.     
❌ Vivid dreams:
Incorrect: Vivid dreams are most commonly associated with efavirenz, which is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI). NNRTIs inhibit viral reverse transcriptase. Additional NNRTIs include delavirdine, efavirenz, and nevirapine. Medications in this class are all associated with rash and hepatotoxicity.   
❌ Bone marrow suppression:
Incorrect: Bone marrow suppression is associated with the use of nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs). NRTIs competitively inhibit nucleotides from binding to reverse transcriptase, thereby terminating DNA chain elongation. Examples of NRTIs include abacavir, didanosine, emtricitabine, lamivudine, stavudine, tenofovir, and zidovudine. These medications can also cause peripheral neuropathy, lactic acidosis, and pancreatitis.  
❌ Hyperglycemia:
Incorrect: Hyperglycemia is most commonly seen with protease inhibitors, such as atazanavir, indinavir, lopinavir, ritonavir, and saquinavir. These medications block viral protease, thereby preventing the cleaving of HIV mRNA and viral maturation. Protease inhibitors are also associated with gastrointestinal intolerance and lipodystrophy.  
✅ Injection site reaction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Two-months ago, the patient was diagnosed with HIV infection and started on combined antiretroviral therapy. Recently, the patient began experiencing anxiety and difficulty concentrating at work. The patient is concerned that they may end up losing their job. The patient has recently been having intense dreams that “feel as if they were real.” The patient does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for this patient’s current symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with difficulty concentrating at work, anxiety, and vivid dreams, which are most likely due to efavirenz-induced central nervous system (CNS) toxicity.

Efavirenz is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) often used as a part of highly active antiretroviral therapy in patients with HIV infection.

The most important adverse effects of efavirenz involve the CNS. They include dizziness, impaired concentration, dysphoria, vivid or disturbing dreams, and insomnia. Patients on efavirenz can also develop a rash during the first few weeks of treatment that subsequently resolves spontaneously and rarely requires drug discontinuation. Other side effects include headaches, increased hepatic transaminases, and elevated serum cholesterol. Finally, efavirenz and delavirdine are contraindicated during pregnancy as they can cause congenital malformations in the fetus.  

Option Analysis

❌ Enfuvirtide:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide inhibits viral entry into the cell by binding to the gp41 protein. The medication can cause skin reactions at the injection site but does not typically cause central nervous system toxicity.  
❌ Nevirapine:
Incorrect: Nevirapine is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor that is known to cause hepatic necrosis and serious cutaneous reactions (e.g. Stevens-Johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis). However, it does not typically affect the central nervous system.  
❌ Didanosine:
Incorrect: Didanosine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) that can cause pancreatitis, presumably due to the chronic accumulation of toxic metabolic products. However, didanosine and other NRTIs do not typically cause central nervous system toxicity.  
❌ Lopinavir:
Incorrect: Lopinavir is a protease inhibitor. Common side effects include hyperglycemia, gastrointestinal irritation (e.g. nausea, diarrhea), and lipodystrophy. The medication does not typically cause central nervous system toxicity.  
✅ Efavirenz:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Six months ago, the patient was diagnosed with HIV infection and started on combined antiretroviral therapy. The patient’s medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Laboratory studies show a decrease in the CD4 count and an increase in viral load despite ongoing treatment. The patient is switched to a new treatment regimen, which includes a drug that acts by preventing viral DNA synthesis without needing to undergo intracellular phosphorylation. Which of the following medications is most likely part of this patient’s new treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
This patient was most likely started on a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI).

NNRTIs (e.g. efavirenz, delavirdine, nevirapine) are noncompetitive viral reverse transcriptase inhibitors that bind to an allosteric regulatory site on reverse transcriptase. Unlike nucleotide/nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs), NNRTIs do not require intracellular phosphorylation for activation.

NNRTIs are used as a part of highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART), which is a combination drug therapy used in the treatment of HIV infection. NNRTIs are rarely used alone since HIV quickly develops resistance to them by point mutation of the reverse transcriptase enzyme. Moreover, these medications have no effect on the completed proviral DNA already incorporated into CD4+ cells. As a result, NNRTIs can slow down disease progression but cannot cure cells that have already been infected.

Side effects include hepatotoxicity (nevirapine), central nervous system toxicity (e.g. insomnia, mood disturbances), vivid dreams (efavirenz), and hypersensitivity reactions (e.g. Stevens-Johnson syndrome).
 

Option Analysis

❌ Emtricitabine:
Incorrect: Emtricitabine inhibits viral DNA synthesis through antagonism of viral reverse transcriptase. However, emtricitabine needs to undergo intracellular phosphorylation before being able to impart its antiviral effects.  
✅ Delavirdine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Raltegravir:
Incorrect: Integrase is an enzyme that helps incorporate the HIV genome into the host chromosome. Integrase inhibitors (e.g. raltegravir) reversibly inhibit HIV integrase. They do not directly inhibit viral DNA synthesis.  
❌ Ritonavir:
Incorrect: Protease is an HIV enzyme that cleaves the polypeptide products of HIV mRNA into their functional parts. Ritonavir is a protease inhibitor and does not directly inhibit viral DNA synthesis.  
❌ Enfuvirtide:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide is a fusion inhibitor that blocks HIV attachment, penetration, and uncoating. The medication binds to the gp41 subunit of the HIV envelope glycoprotein, thereby preventing conformational changes and inhibiting viral fusion with T-cells.

questions.text: A newborn boy is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit for cyanosis after being born to a 30-year-old woman via a normal vaginal delivery at 38 weeks gestation. The mother had poor prenatal care and follow up. Temperature is 38.7 C (101.7 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg. Pulse oximetry shows 80% oxygen saturation on room air. Physical examination demonstrates a hypoplastic mandible, cleft palate, orbital hypertelorism, and bifid uvula. Chest x-ray shows decreased soft tissue attenuation in the right anterior mediastinum. Echocardiographic findings are consistent with Tetralogy of Fallot. A genetic disorder with pure T-cell dysfunction is suspected. Which of the following modalities would be most useful to confirm the genetic abnormality underlying this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This infant presents with cyanosis at birth, abnormal facies, absence of thymic shadow on chest x-ray, and Tetralogy of Fallot--suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome (DGS). This syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder which results from a microdeletion at chromosome 22q11.2, and it is best diagnosed via fluorescence in situ hybridization.

The diagnosis of DGS is based upon a reduced number of CD3+ T cells in combination with either  characteristic clinical findings or a demonstrated microdeletion on chromosome 22q11.2. Genetic analysis is normally performed using fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH), which is more sensitive than the standard karyotyping and can be applied to both dividing (metaphase) and non-dividing cells (interphase). It uses a single-stranded complementary DNA segment tagged with a radiotracer specific for the localization of genes, allowing for direct visualization of chromosomal anomalies at the molecular level. In the case of DGS, FISH would demonstrate absence of fluorescence on the affected chromosome 22q11.2 compared to fluorescence at the same locus on the second copy of unaffected chromosome 22.


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Karyotyping:
Incorrect: With karyotyping, chromosomes are stained, ordered, and numbered according to morphology, size, arm-length ratio, and banding pattern. It is usually used to diagnose chromosomal imbalances (e.g., autosomal trisomies and sex chromosome disorders). FISH, however, is more reliable for the definitive diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome.  
✅ Fluorescence in situ hybridization:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Flow cytometry:
Incorrect: Flow cytometry is commonly used for workup of hematologic abnormalities and immunodeficiencies. This technique evaluates surface markers of individual cells, not chromosomal deletions.
❌ Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay:
Incorrect: Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is an immunologic test used to identify specific antibodies or antigens in a patient’s blood sample. It cannot detect chromosomal microdeletions.
❌ Western blotting:
Incorrect: Western blotting is a technique that employs proteins in a gel followed by administration of  antibodies to target specific proteins. It is often used to confirm a positive ELISA test for HIV or Lyme disease.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy is admitted for cervical lymphadenitis secondary to Staphylococcus aureus. Past medical history is significant for pneumonia due to Klebsiella pneumoniae, as well as recurrent fevers and multiple skin infections. Family history is non-contributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 25/min, blood pressure is 90/46 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals bilateral enlarged cervical lymph nodes with associated erythema and tenderness to palpation. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate test to confirm the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's history of recurrent infections with catalase-positive organisms is consistent with chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). A positive dihydrorhodamine test confirms the diagnosis.       

The initial evaluation of a patient with suspected primary immunodeficiency includes a detailed history, physical examination, and laboratory studies, along with an assessment for characteristic features of associated syndromes. In the absence of such features, identifying the types of microbes causing infections can help narrow the differential diagnosis. Recurrent infections with catalase-positive organisms (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus, Serratia, Klebsiella, Nocardia) should raise suspicion for CGD, which is confirmed by demonstrating decreased phagocytic oxidase activity on flow cytometry using the dihydrorhodamine test.        

Polymicrobial infections involving both aerobic and anaerobic organisms may suggest leukocyte adhesion deficiency, which is diagnosed by flow cytometry assessing neutrophil adhesion glycoproteins. Infections with extracellular encapsulated bacteria, particularly invasive Neisseria meningitidis, may indicate complement deficiency, confirmed by reduced CH50 and AH50 activity. Recurrent sinopulmonary or gastrointestinal infections with encapsulated organisms should prompt evaluation for B-cell or antibody defects, typically assessed with quantitative immunoglobulin levels, flow cytometry, and genetic testing depending on the suspected condition.   

Option Analysis

❌ Total complement levels:
Incorrect: Complement deficiency typically presents with recurrent infections due to encapsulated organisms such as Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae. This patient’s history of recurrent infections with catalase-positive organisms is more consistent with chronic granulomatous disease. Dihydrorhodamine flow cytometry is the preferred diagnostic test. 
✅ Dihydrorhodamine flow cytometry:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Platelet count:
Incorrect: Thrombocytopenia may be seen in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, which presents with eczema and recurrent infections due to encapsulated organisms. This patient's history of multiple infections with catalase-positive organisms is more consistent with chronic granulomatous disease. 
❌ Quantitative immunoglobulins:
Incorrect: This test is useful in the evaluation of B-cell immunodeficiencies such as X-linked agammaglobulinemia, which often presents with absent or small lymphoid tissues. The presence of palpable lymph nodes and catalase-positive infections makes this diagnosis less likely. 
❌ T-cell flow cytometry:
Incorrect: T-cell flow cytometry is used in evaluating T-cell deficiencies such as DiGeorge syndrome, which presents with recurrent viral or fungal infections, hypocalcemia-related seizures, characteristic facies, and congenital heart defects. These findings are not present in this case.

questions.text:
A 1-month-old infant presents with delayed cord separation. Pregnancy and delivery were uneventful. Past medical history is significant for two episodes of otitis media. The patient has no rash, vomiting, or diarrhea. Temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 190/min, respirations are 33/min, blood pressure is 75/40 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, the umbilical cord appears attached with an erythematous and tense umbilical stump. A complete blood cell count (CBC) is shown below. Immunoglobulin levels are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?  

 Laboratory value     Result    
           Complete blood count (CBC)         
 Hemoglobin     16 g/dL    
 Hematocrit     45 %    
 Leukocyte count     59,100 /mm3    
 Platelet count     400,000/mm3    
 Neutrophils     78%    
 Eosinophils     0%    
 Basophils     0%    
 Lymphocytes     20%    
 Monocytes     2%
questions.solution:
This child's history of recurrent infections, delayed umbilical cord separation, and physical exam findings of omphalitis without purulence are characteristic of leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD). The laboratory studies showing marked neutrophilic leukocytosis with normal immunoglobulin levels further support the diagnosis. LAD results from impaired neutrophil adhesion and migration due to defective integrins, particularly CD18, which can be evaluated by flow cytometry.       

In patients with suspected primary immunodeficiency and no distinguishing syndromic features, the type of infection and causative organisms can help narrow the differential diagnosis and guide the diagnostic process.        

LAD typically presents polymicrobial skin and mucosal infections, delayed cord separation, ulcers without pus, and gingivitis. Labs may show marked neutrophilic leukocytosis and normal immunoglobulin levels. Flow cytometry demonstrates decreased expression of CD18 or CD11 on neutrophils.        

In contrast, chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) involves recurrent infections with catalase-positive organisms. Immunoglobulin levels are usually normal, and the CBC may show mild leukocytosis. Diagnosis is confirmed by the dihydrorhodamine (DHR) flow cytometry test for oxidative burst.        

Complement deficiencies often result in invasive infections with encapsulated bacteria, especially Neisseria meningitidis, with normal CBC and immunoglobulin levels. Diagnosis is made using CH50 and AH50 assays.         

B-cell or antibody deficiencies present with recurrent sinopulmonary or gastrointestinal infections, lymphopenia on CBC, and characteristic immunoglobulin level patterns. Diagnosis includes quantitative immunoglobulin testing, flow cytometry, and genetic analysis as indicated.   

Option Analysis

❌ Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation :
Incorrect: Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is the treatment of choice for leukocyte adhesion deficiency. However, flow cytometry is required to confirm the diagnosis prior to referral.  
❌ Genetic testing :
Incorrect: Genetic testing can be useful for the diagnosis of primary immunodeficiencies such as ataxia telangiectasia, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, and hyper IgM syndrome. This patient's presentation is most consistent with leukocyte adhesion deficiency, and flow cytometry is required to confirm the diagnosis. 
✅ Flow cytometry :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Immunology referral :
Incorrect: While referral to an immunologist is appropriate for long-term management of suspected immunodeficiency, diagnostic confirmation with flow cytometry is the priority. 
❌ Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) serology  :
Incorrect: Perinatal HIV infection typically presents with opportunistic infections, failure to thrive, or chronic symptoms such as diarrhea. Delayed cord separation and marked neutrophilia are not characteristic of HIV but suggest leukocyte adhesion deficiency.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department with a 2-day history of cough, decreased oral intake, and high fever (up to 40°C) unresponsive to antipyretics. There is no history of vomiting, seizures, or rhinorrhea. The infant has a history of recurrent ear infections and persistent diarrhea for one month. Birth and family histories are noncontributory. Temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 198/min, respirations are 54/min, blood pressure is 75/40 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals a white film over the tongue and buccal mucosa, as well as a flaky, dandruff-like rash over the scalp and face. Capillary refill is 2 seconds, and mucous membranes are moist. Cardiopulmonary exam shows tachycardia and tachypnea. Abdominal and neurologic exams are normal. Laboratory findings include a decreased lymphocyte count. A chest radiograph reveals an absent thymic shadow. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This infant has severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) and presents with signs of sepsis. The history of chronic diarrhea, recurrent infections, oral thrush, and a flaky rash suggestive of Omenn syndrome, along with laboratory findings of lymphopenia and an absent thymic shadow on chest radiograph, support the diagnosis. Although further evaluation for immunodeficiency is warranted, the best next step in management is initiation of empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics to stabilize the patient.        

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) is a life-threatening primary immunodeficiency caused by genetic mutations that result in profound T- and B-cell dysfunction. It typically presents in infants younger than 6 months with features such as failure to thrive, chronic diarrhea, oral thrush, and recurrent infections. Physical examination may reveal mucocutaneous candidiasis, oral ulcers, and decreased or absent lymphoid tissue. Some patients exhibit signs of Omenn syndrome, including scaly erythematous skin, alopecia, and peripheral edema (see image below). Laboratory findings often show decreased lymphocyte counts and low immunoglobulin levels, with impaired T- and B-cell numbers or function. Chest radiographs commonly demonstrate a small or absent thymus.        

An ABCDE assessment should be performed for any patient presenting with suspected primary immunodeficiency. The initial priority is to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation in unstable patients. Once stabilized, continuous vital sign monitoring and supplemental oxygen as needed should follow. Emergent initiation of empiric antibiotics is a cornerstone of acute management, and immunoglobulin therapy should be considered. Long-term treatment includes hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, avoidance of live vaccines, antimicrobial prophylaxis, and protective isolation.   


A 5-month-old female infant with Omenn syndrome. Reproduced from Wikipedia. Licensed under CC BY 2.0. 

Option Analysis

❌ Outpatient immunology referral :
Incorrect: Referral to immunology on an outpatient basis is inappropriate for an infant with suspected severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) and signs of systemic infection. Prompt inpatient evaluation and empiric treatment are critical. 
❌ Intravenous vasopressors :
Incorrect: Although the patient meets criteria for sepsis, the blood pressure is within the normal range for age, and perfusion appears adequate. Vasopressors are not indicated before initiating fluid resuscitation and empiric antibiotic therapy. 
✅ Intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Flow cytometry  :
Incorrect: Flow cytometry is an important diagnostic tool for evaluating suspected severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). However, in a patient presenting with sepsis, empiric antibiotic therapy takes priority over diagnostic testing. 
❌ Bone marrow biopsy :
Incorrect: Bone marrow biopsy may be used to support the diagnosis of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) and guide preparation for hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. However, it is not part of the initial workup, and initiating empiric antibiotics is the priority in a patient presenting with signs of sepsis.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy presents to clinic with a parent for evaluation of persistent eczema. Medical history is significant for frequent respiratory tract infections. Birth and family histories are non-contributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 96/58 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals eczematous lesions over the elbows and knees with associated excoriation. No dysmorphic features are noted. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are normal. Laboratory studies are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Serum chemistries         
 Hemoglobin     12 g/dL    
 Hematocrit     40 %    
 Leukocyte count     9,100 /mm3    
 Platelet count     80,000/mm3
questions.solution:
This child presents with eczema and recurrent respiratory tract infections. The initial evaluation reveals normal facies, eczematous skin, and thrombocytopenia, findings consistent with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS).        

Primary immunodeficiencies often present with recurrent, severe, or opportunistic infections. Additional clues may include an abnormal newborn screen, a personal history of autoimmune disease, or a family history of immunodeficiency. Poor growth and suboptimal weight gain may also be seen on the growth chart. When evaluating such patients, the next step is to look for characteristic clinical features that suggest a specific syndrome.        

Eczema is seen in both Hyper-IgE syndrome and Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS). To help distinguish between them, assess for coarse facial features. If present, consider Hyper-IgE syndrome, which may also present with skin abscesses lacking overt inflammation. In contrast, eczema without coarse facies should raise concern for WAS.      
 
WAS is an X-linked immunodeficiency characterized by recurrent sinopulmonary infections (particularly with Streptococcus pneumoniae), eczema, prolonged bleeding, bloody diarrhea, and abnormal lymphocyte function. Due to its X-linked recessive inheritance, most affected patients are biologically male. Clinical findings typically include eczema and purpura, and laboratory evaluation reveals thrombocytopenia, decreased IgM, elevated IgA and IgE, and sometimes decreased IgG. Diagnosis is confirmed with genetic analysis of the WASP gene.   

Option Analysis

❌ Chediak-Higashi syndrome :
Incorrect: Chediak-Higashi syndrome may present with recurrent infections and bleeding due to platelet dysfunction, but it is typically associated with partial oculocutaneous albinism.  
❌ DiGeorge syndrome :
Incorrect: Although this patient has recurrent infections, the absence of seizures and congenital heart defects, along with the presence of eczema and thrombocytopenia, makes DiGeorge syndrome less likely. 
❌ Hyper-IgE syndrome :
Incorrect: Ezema is a common feature of Hyper-IgE syndrome. However, the absence of coarse facial features and the presence of thrombocytopenia are more consistent with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. 
❌ Hyper-IgM syndrome  :
Incorrect: Hyper-IgM syndrome is associated with recurrent opportunistic infections and may present with osteopenia, fractures, diarrhea, or inflammatory bowel disease. Eczema and thrombocytopenia are not characteristic findings.  
✅ Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of respiratory distress. About 30 minutes ago the patient was eating lunch at a restaurant with a group of friends when she suddenly started feeling shortness of breath. The patient has a history of asthma and eczema. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, blood pressure is 93/64 mmHg, respiratory rate is 26/min, and oxygen saturation is 89% on room air. The patient can speak in full sentences but uses accessory muscles to breathe. Auscultation of the lungs reveals bilateral wheezes. There is an urticarial rash on the bilateral upper extremities. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This young woman’s presentation of shortness of breath, increased respiratory effort, and an urticarial rash after exposure to a likely unknown inciting agent while eating is highly suggestive of anaphylaxis. Anaphylaxis refers to an acute, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that occurs upon second exposure after sensitization to an antigen. IgE-mediated activation of basophils and mast cells leads to the release of pro-inflammatory mediators (e.g., histamine, prostaglandins, cytokines). These mediators cause an overwhelming systemic inflammatory reaction that can ultimately result in anaphylactic shock or even death.

If anaphylaxis is suspected, immediate intramuscular epinephrine (typically in the lateral thigh) should be administered, even before obtaining a history and physical examination. Epinephrine raises blood pressure, reduces bronchospasm, and counteracts other effects of circulating inflammatory mediators.
 

Following administration of epinephrine, an ABCDE (Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure) assessment should be performed to determine if the patient is unstable or stable. If the patient is unstable, stabilization of the airway and volume resuscitation should occur. Endotracheal intubation should be performed if there is concern for impending respiratory failure; this should be done as soon as possible since airway edema can progress quickly and make intubation difficult. Obtaining IV access is critically important as well; if the patient is hypotensive, IV fluids for volume resuscitation should be started as soon as possible.  

Option Analysis

✅ Intramuscular administration of epinephrine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Intravenous diphenhydramine:
Incorrect: Diphenhydramine is an antihistamine that can help to relieve itching and hives in anaphylaxis, but it does not address the potentially life-threatening symptoms of anaphylaxis such as hypotension, respiratory distress, and airway obstruction. It can be administered once epinephrine is given.   
❌ Administer nebulized albuterol   :
Incorrect: Nebulized albuterol is a bronchodilator that can help to relieve bronchoconstriction, which is a common symptom of anaphylaxis. However, it does not address the other potentially life-threatening symptoms of anaphylaxis such as hypotension and airway obstruction. It can be given once epinephrine is administered.   
❌ Intravenous fluids:
Incorrect: Administering IV fluids may be necessary to maintain blood pressure in patients with anaphylaxis, but it is not the most appropriate immediate next step in the management of anaphylaxis. Anaphylaxis is a rapidly progressive and potentially life-threatening condition that requires immediate treatment with epinephrine to prevent further deterioration.   
❌ Endotracheal intubation:
Incorrect: Respiratory distress can occur in anaphylaxis, as seen in this patient, and endotracheal intubation may be necessary for this patient. However, epinephrine should be administered first as this may lead to significant improvement in the patient’s condition.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is brought into the emergency department by her partner for evaluation of shortness of breath. The patient has a history of asthma. Current medications include an albuterol inhaler. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, blood pressure is 120/76 mmHg, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. The patient is able to speak in full sentences and is not using accessory muscles to breathe. Auscultation of the lungs reveals bilateral wheezes. There is an urticarial rash seen on the bilateral upper extremities, abdomen, and trunk. The abdomen is mildly tender to palpation. Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with shortness of breath and an urticarial rash after a likely exposure to an unknown inciting agent has anaphylaxis. Anaphylaxis refers to an acute, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that occurs upon second exposure after sensitization to an antigen. IgE-mediated activation of basophils and mast cells leads to the release of pro-inflammatory mediators (e.g., tryptase, tumor necrosis factor, histamine, and prostaglandins). These mediators cause an overwhelming systemic inflammatory reaction that can ultimately result in anaphylactic shock or even death.

Laboratory findings can sometimes be useful in patients presenting with anaphylaxis; however, it is a clinical diagnosis and clinical signs and symptoms must be recognized early to prevent catastrophic complications. Laboratory studies may occasionally show signs of end-organ damage but are not necessary for the diagnosis of anaphylaxis. An elevated serum tryptase level will confirm the diagnosis if it is not already clear by the history and physical. However, tryptase levels do not peak until 1 to 1.5 hours after the onset of symptoms. Elevated histamine and tumor necrosis factor levels can be indicators of anaphylaxis but are not routinely measured.  

Option Analysis

✅ Increased serum tryptase   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Increased serum immunoglobulin A   :
Incorrect: IgE is an immunoglobulin that plays a critical role in allergic reactions and is elevated in patients with atopic conditions and allergies. During anaphylaxis, IgE mediates the activation of mast cells and basophils leading to the release of histamine and other mediators. IgA does not play a role in anaphylaxis.   
❌ Decreased tumor necrosis factor   :
Incorrect: Tumor necrosis factor is one of the pro-inflammatory cytokines that is released and elevated during anaphylaxis.   
❌ Decreased histamine   :
Incorrect: Histamine is one of the pro-inflammatory mediators, along with tryptase and tumor necrosis factor, that are released and elevated during anaphylaxis.   
❌ Decreased prostaglandins   :
Incorrect:  Prostaglandin is one of the pro-inflammatory mediators, along with tryptase and tumor necrosis factor, that are released and elevated during anaphylaxis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of shortness of breath. About 30 minutes ago the patient was stung by a bee while hiking and quickly became short of breath and vomited once. The patient has a known allergy to bee stings but misplaced her epinephrine auto-injector several months ago. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, blood pressure is 115/65 mmHg, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. The patient is not using accessory muscles but appears to have difficulty breathing. Lung auscultation reveals diffuse wheezes bilaterally. There is an urticarial rash on the bilateral upper extremities. Paramedics administered one dose of intramuscular epinephrine in the ambulance while en route to the hospital. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Administration of a second dose of intramuscular epinephrine

questions.solution:
This patient presenting with shortness of breath, vomiting, and an urticarial rash after exposure to a known inciting agent has anaphylaxis. Anaphylaxis refers to an acute, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that occurs upon second exposure after sensitization to an antigen. IgE-mediated activation of basophils and mast cells leads to the release of pro-inflammatory mediators (e.g., histamine, prostaglandins, cytokines). These mediators cause an overwhelming systemic inflammatory reaction that can ultimately result in anaphylactic shock or even death.

If anaphylaxis is suspected, intramuscular epinephrine should be administered immediately (typically in the lateral thigh), even before obtaining a history and physical examination. Epinephrine raises blood pressure, reduces bronchospasm, and counteracts other effects of circulating inflammatory mediators.

It is important for clinicians to recognize that patients may need multiple doses of epinephrine (up to 3). Most patients respond to a single dose of IM epinephrine, particularly if it is given promptly after the onset of symptoms. IM epinephrine may be repeated at 5- to 15-minute intervals if there is no response or inadequate response. In severe cases where IM epinephrine is inadequate, a slow, continuous infusion of epinephrine can be used.

H1 and H2 antihistamines and corticosteroids can be given as adjunctive therapy with epinephrine but they should not be given alone. They do not prevent or treat bronchoconstriction or hypotension that can be associated with anaphylaxis.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Administration of a second dose of intramuscular epinephrine   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Immediate endotracheal intubation   :
Incorrect: While respiratory distress and airway obstruction can occur in anaphylaxis, this patient is not using accessory muscles to breathe and should be given a second dose of epinephrine. Most patients improve after 1 or 2 doses, although up to 3 doses can be given.   
❌ Administration of intravenous fluids   :
Incorrect: Administration of IV fluids may be necessary to maintain blood pressure in patients with anaphylaxis; however, this patient is not currently hypotensive. This patient should immediately be given a second dose of epinephrine since symptoms have not resolved with the first dose.   
❌ Administration of intravenous diphenhydramine   :
Incorrect: Diphenhydramine is a first-generation antihistamine that can help to relieve itching and hives, but it does not address the potentially life-threatening symptoms of anaphylaxis such as hypotension, respiratory distress, and airway obstruction.   
❌ Administration of nebulized albuterol   :
Incorrect: Nebulized albuterol is a bronchodilator that can help to relieve bronchoconstriction, which is a common symptom of anaphylaxis. However, it does not address the other potentially life-threatening symptoms of anaphylaxis such as hypotension and airway obstruction.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man is brought into the emergency department by his significant other for evaluation of respiratory distress. The patient has a history of asthma and eczema. Symptoms began while the patient was eating lunch at a local park. Current medications include an albuterol inhaler and a fluticasone-salmeterol inhaler. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6°F), blood pulse is 112/min, pressure is 91/59 mmHg, respiratory rate is 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. The patient has stridorous breath sounds. Auscultation of the lungs reveals bilateral wheezes. There is an urticarial rash seen on the bilateral upper extremities. The abdomen is mildly tender to palpation. Which of the following questions would be most relevant at this time?

choices.text: “Do you have any allergies to foods or insects?”
“Have you been using your inhalers for your asthma?”
“Have you had a recent productive cough?”
“Have you used an electronic cigarette recently?”

questions.solution:
This young man presenting with shortness of breath, increased respiratory effort, and an urticarial rash after exposure to a likely unknown inciting agent has anaphylaxis. Anaphylaxis refers to an acute, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that occurs upon second exposure after sensitization to an antigen. IgE-mediated activation of basophils and mast cells leads to the release of pro-inflammatory mediators (e.g., histamine, prostaglandins, cytokines). These mediators cause an overwhelming systemic inflammatory reaction that can ultimately result in anaphylactic shock or even death.

If anaphylaxis is suspected, immediate intramuscular epinephrine (typically in the lateral thigh) should be administered, even before obtaining a history and physical examination, to resolve the anaphylaxis and prevent shock.

History often reveals definite or suspected recent allergen exposure, but in some cases, the trigger can remain unknown. Physical examination typically shows mucocutaneous, respiratory, cardiovascular, and gastrointestinal findings. Common mucocutaneous findings include urticaria with intense pruritus and edema of the mucous membranes. In severe cases, laryngeal edema can develop and cause voice hoarseness and stridor. Respiratory findings include labored breathing and wheezing, while cardiovascular manifestations include hypotension and syncope. In addition, if the gastrointestinal system is affected, the patient might have crampy abdominal pain and vomiting. Laboratory studies will show an elevated tryptase level which can confirm the diagnosis if it is not already clear by the history and physical. However, tryptase levels do not peak until 1 to 1.5 hours after the onset of symptoms.  

Option Analysis

✅ “Do you have any allergies to foods or insects?”   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ “Have you been using your inhalers for your asthma?”   :
Incorrect: While an asthma exacerbation may present as acute respiratory distress with the presence of wheezes on physical examination, this patient’s rapid progression of symptoms and urticarial rash suggest an alternate diagnosis.   
❌ “Have you recently traveled?”   :
Incorrect: Travel to regions with endemic pathogens (e.g., Histoplasma, Coccidioides) can result in lung disease. These pathogens typically follow a more indolent disease course and would not present as acutely as this patient’s current symptoms.   
❌ “Have you had a recent productive cough?”   :
Incorrect: Pneumonia can result in respiratory failure, especially in patients with other comorbidities or with immunosuppression. This patient is a relatively healthy, young man and the rapidly developing symptoms and urticarial rash are best explained by anaphylaxis.   
❌ “Have you used an electronic cigarette recently?”   :
Incorrect: E-cigarette or vaping product use-associated lung injury (EVALI) is an acute or subacute respiratory illness. EVALI is a clinical diagnosis that requires the use of an e-cigarette in the 90 days preceding the appearance of initial symptoms; pulmonary infiltrates on chest imaging, and the absence of any more likely etiology. This patient’s rapidly developing symptoms and urticarial rash are best explained by anaphylaxis.
